text: [Music]
hey guys thanks for being here uh my
name is Danny Makov uh I work for a
company called uh Just Another Framework
uh or Jaff Labs and uh today I'm going
to be talking about WOMP powered dev
environments and I'm really excited to
do it because I think they're
cool so what we will cover uh first uh
is just a little bit about some of the
current workflows that people go through
when writing software today and what
some of the pain points are that are
pretty common uh and how WoM can help
alleviate some of the pain that we
encounter when we write software today
um via these WM powered dev environments
and then uh the middle part will be kind
of for the nerds uh and we'll be uh
diving into the weeds about how we're
actually accomplishing uh the
implementation of these WIME powered dev
environments um and then we'll get to
the exciting part where we're actually
demonstrating you know writing our
software in these dev environments and
compiling them on the fly uh and uh yeah
you can get a taste for what it's like
to use these things
so firstly um a friend showed me this
gif recently when they were talking
about a pull request uh that was really
bothering them and it just kind of
resonated with me at my core so
basically you've got like the dad from
uh Malcolm in the Middle trying to
change a light bulb but then like every
single tool that he wants to use along
the way also doesn't work uh and so he
has to fix like thing after thing and
till he ends up trying to fix his car
but yeah uh and it's like what does it
look like I'm trying to do and so this
really is kind of the case when you go
and you uh clone a new repo on GitHub uh
the number of things that you frequently
have to do before you can start editing
any code you might realize like oh this
thing is dockerized and I don't have uh
Docker Desktop installed so let me go
get that and then you look at the Docker
file and it needs you to put in an API
key uh for some service that you've
never heard of before and so then you
have to go figure out what like it
requires to access one of those and then
uh maybe you find out that uh they
recently switched from like Webpack to
Vit and you have to deal with that and
then there's like a whole bunch of Sever
stuff and things with like breaking
changes and all of this is not writing
code which is the thing that you're
trying to do um and so what we thought
is that these WAMP powered dev
environments might be able to let us
focus on the thing that we're actually
trying to do and the other thing that
I'd just like to comment on too is like
how prohibitive this is for people who
are like trying to get into software
right like when you're trying to learn a
new programming language that's like a
whole set of concepts that are like the
syntax that's involved in Python but
then it can be really intimidating when
you have to spend the first 3 hours of
your development session doing all these
things that are not learning how the
language actually works and instead
basically dealing with the fact that
your house is broken uh instead of
actually changing the light bulb right
so um
yeah so the way we're doing this is with
these WAM dev environments what are
these WAM dev environments um basically
um we have this thing that we're calling
edit.dev and we've got like a little uh
conference domain uh that we'll be
showing off later but in it there is a
uh text editor so you actually can
author your source code in the browser
um but what we're doing that's a little
bit unique is we actually have the
compiler running in the browser itself
um in the example that we'll be
demonstrating today we've actually got
uh like Rust C compiled to WOM so the
Rust compiler is able to be invoked by
the browser because browsers understand
WOM and then it's turning the Rust code
into more WOM and you can then actually
run the application that you're
authoring uh all without like the whole
thing happens inside of the browser um
and we're even uh for the backend
services that we're authoring we're
actually uh having those interact with
the service worker that we've registered
so it'll intercept HTTP requests and uh
you can even actually have like your
backend services running in the browser
um which is pretty cool and uh there's
not really anything that is special
about Rust here uh it's just the one
it's the compiler that we compiled to
Wom for the demo but there's no reason
that you couldn't do this with any other
compiler or even an interpreter so you
could you know do this with like
JavaScript or Python or you know
anything um and then the other thing
that's cool about this is that uh you
have a link at the end of the day so if
you've you know authored some code you
can just say hey teammate I want you to
check this out they don't have to clone
anything they don't have to do anything
on their machine they open it they see
the code they run it that's all that
they have to
do so the benefits of this as uh
indicated earlier is that there is uh no
configuration or installation hassle it
just you open a link and there it is uh
and then this local first uh it really
lets you do things in a local first way
so actually I'll have like an example
where if you you know we've seen a lot
of people using things like uh SQLite
and like duct DB compiled to WM in the
browser so if your persistence layer
doesn't actually require that you
interact with a network your HTTP
services can just be running and you
could like turn off your Wi-Fi and like
work on an airplane right um so that's
also another thing that is pretty cool
about this stuff and then yeah basically
we'd love to have it where you know
here's the code here i'm gonna like edit
it and then send you my link and you can
actually see what the latest changes are
if you don't understand what's going on
you can add debug statements and
recompile the code and it is just live
updating as you're editing in your
browser and uh the reason we built this
is because this is how we want to author
our code we're tired of like saying to
somebody like hey use this branch and
when you use this branch actually you
have to use this other like red
dockerize things in order to get things
to work with this feature and like you
know use the test environment instead of
the you know all of that is just like we
don't want to spend time thinking about
it we want to just be able to easily
access the code so the way that it works
as I indicated is um we're compiling the
Rust compiler to Wom we have this Rust
C.Wom there was some prior art that we
used as a starting point that I can show
you guys um I decided to link to this
repo because it also has a link to a
bunch of the other repos that were used
that kind of uh we used for inspiration
and so a big step that happened was this
person here White Cork um you know did a
lot of great work in order to make it
possible to use LLVM when compiling to
Wom and then this other person Bjorn 3
uh has like a fork of the Rust compiler
that leverages the work that White Quark
did and so that was was like the first
time that I saw the Rust compiler
successfully compiled to Wom and working
and then the maintainer of this repo uh
is this uh Ogami and they actually like
have a link here that I can just show
you guys really quick where they
actually have you know the same thing
that I'm kind of describing here uh you
can edit Rust code here you can select
what you want your uh target to be um
you could like you know say that you
wanted it to be Wom and then you can
compile and run this um and it's really
cool if you want to like really
understand the details of how to compile
the Rust compile to Wom uh like this
repo is like a really good starting
point and it's where we started um there
are some things that are worth remarking
on about
that and so one of them is that it
produces core WOM modules um and for us
we felt that we needed to leverage the
component model in order to make it so
that people could do things
ergonomically um and like have these
full stack uh web applications that I'm
describing that they're authoring using
these dev environments um and so yeah
I'll talk more about the component model
in the next slides um but then the other
thing too is that it requires an
implementation of WY P1 threads which is
itself like an interesting you don't see
it used that much um basically there's
like a very lively discussion going on
about the long-term usage of threads in
WOM um P1 threads was like an early
thing you can use it i don't think that
there's an intention to like maintain it
long term but like at the moment we
needed to use it because Rustc has to
spawn threads um and we do think that we
probably can find a way to potentially
not need to invoke threads and you know
that's something we're going to continue
to tinker with but we currently have a
WYP1 threads in JavaScript and we also
used that prior art as inspiration when
uh going uh to implement our own
implementation of Wazzy P1 threads
and so the component model the really
the main thing is that we wanted people
to be able to author back-end services
and we wanted their code to look pretty
similar to the code that they're used to
writing and I do know people who you
know use a network from core WOM but uh
when you're using core WOM you've got
the whole thing of the only types that
there are are numbers and you're
manually writing things to an array
buffer and it doesn't look like the code
that you usually write right and we
wanted people to not have to learn
things in order to do this and the
standard that is uh you know defined in
wy http makes this really easy there's
also a crate called w stood for rust
that I'll be talking about as well that
you'll see we're heavily leveraging in
the app that we're using and then yeah
also you know there are all of these uh
you know value propositions that people
always bring up when it comes to WOM the
secure sandbox the portability uh when
you can you know run your code in the
browser or on the server uh polyglot and
all that but with the component model
you also get composability um and we
also happen to have made a uh WOM
registry called WA.dev where you can
easily take two uh you know WOM
components that were created
independently of each other and import
and export functionality from each other
so we're really excited too to leverage
the component model and have people be
able to gra use WOM that's already been
used uh inside of these dev environments
and again that's only possible with the
component model and so for the process
of componentization there are basically
uh two kind of strategies that compilers
are using right now um I'll start off
just talking about Rust rust has
generally been kind of a
uh pioneer in you know adopting the
component model um basically whenever
there's kind of new stuff available to
use in Wom Rust usually makes use of it
first and then you see other languages
start to do it so initially you the way
that people were creating components is
there's this adapter module and you
basically would just compile your code
into a core WOM module uh and then with
this adapter module you can provide a a
wit file and then you using this project
called WM tools you can just turn that
core WM module into a component and
initially like Rust was the first one to
do that and then they and then other
languages started doing it and then Rust
actually added WYP2 as a target that it
supports uh like in the stable build of
the Rust compiler so actually like right
now you do not need to do the adapter
module process uh manually at all uh if
you just do like d- you know wazzy p2
when you do your rust compilation it
will generate a component uh and I think
that there's been some work with like
tiny go they might be able to do this
too but for the most part the other
languages are still using the adapter
module the thing is is that when you try
to use uh the compiler compiled to wom
this rust c.wmom Wom like almost 90% of
the difficulties stem from getting
linking to work between like your
different binaries uh and like having
your dependencies link properly and so
we found that when trying to use the P2
target that is uh you know supported out
of the box with rusty.wom we had issues
with linking so what we're doing in the
browser is actually compiling things to
the P1 target and then we compiled WOM
tools to WOM as well so in the browser
we're actually using WOM tools to adapt
our core WOM modules into components and
what's nice about this is because other
languages for most of them don't have a
P2 target out of the box yet like this
is what makes it generalizable like the
language maintainers do not need to add
a component like do any work to like
support the component model you can use
Wom tools to so if you compiled like the
Go compiler to Wom you could do the same
process without needing to wait for
there to be component model support in
Go um and then async I wanted to talk a
little bit about that as well so we're
currently using WYP2 there have been
talks at this conference uh about WYP3
which is coming up and people talk about
uh WYP3 as enabling async but you will
notice in the demo that we're doing
we're using async aait and so I just
wanted to point out that even though P3
is all about
async it's about async aait at the
boundary of components so when you're
like doing composition whether you want
to whether the exported functionality
can be called asynchronously or whether
you can import something and call it
asynchronously um but today with P2 WyO
enables you to do async await and this
leans heavily on this W stood crate um
but basically there's a pullable object
in WY.io uh that you can use and then
because we're executing things uh in the
browser we're actually using JSPI which
is a kind of an experimental uh web API
that uh it's the JavaScript uh promise
integration for WOM and so we're using
that it is currently um like in the demo
that we're using it is a uh you can use
JSPI as a cross origin trial so we have
it like activated for this domain so
like in order to use our demo you would
either have to use Chrome because it's
not in all of the browsers yet or I do
believe it is behind a feature flag in
Firefox um but basically we'll see JSPI
coming out there are other things you
can use like asyncify but uh you know
for this demo we decided to use JSPI and
yeah so these wy primitives that let you
deal with like blocking and non-blocking
logic um so that you could do things
like async are themselves pretty low
level um and not what people are
generally used to writing they're used
to writing async await uh and so wto
basically kind of has all of the logic
for making it so that you can just do
async await and it builds all of that
out of the wyio primitives so if you
want to check out that repo it's also
really interesting and then it also
provides like a bunch of stuff too for
dealing with HTTP requests the way that
you're used to so you can like actually
have an HTTP request builder and you
know there's like a body method for
setting like the JSON body and you can
set the HTTP method and query parameters
and headers and all that stuff in a way
that feels like what you actually are
used to doing when you're not thinking
about
WOM and then the final thing that I'll
uh say uh about how we're doing things
is that you can't compile cargo to WM
today uh and most people who are
building their Rust projects are totally
doing it with cargo um but basically if
you're accessing the network from your
Wom you need to be leveraging wi HTTP
and doing something like what WTO is
doing so probably at some point some
further iteration of something similar
to WTO will be able to be you know added
to like the request like the HTTP crates
that people want and then you would be
able to do that but that would be like a
pretty big PR like into cargo in order
to enable that also cargo cargo is
highly parallelized i was mentioning
before that the thread story like is
still like live and active and growing
so we're basically like manually doing
what Cargo is doing for the uh actual uh
like demo app that we're do uh building
that we're about to show you we knew
what dependencies we were going to be
using ahead of time so like at the
moment you can't use our thing to
dynamically add crates unless it's a
crate that we've already done a build
for and this is something that we're
very eager to you know work more on and
make it so that you can just grab
whatever crate you want but the one of
the benefits of this that you'll see is
that you can cache a dependency in one
project and then you know as we have
support for having multiple projects
once it's cached in the browser you can
reuse it so you'll see that when we are
compiling stuff in the browser we have
these caches and we're only building the
code that is like the source like the
top level not any of the dependencies
and you can end up with pretty fast uh
compilation times we'll be doing most of
our compilations in like less than 3
seconds because we've already cached all
the builds for all the
dependencies and so yeah we'll talk a
little bit about the uh architecture for
the app that we have too so basically
we're using wto I provides a router is
maybe weird wording you you have the
ability to check what the route is on an
inbound HTTP request when you're writing
like something that responds to HTTP
requests and so we basically just have a
match statement uh that checks whether
the route that is being requested uh is
one of the ones that is handled in the
source code that is being compiled to
WOM and we again have this uh registered
with a service worker that is
intercepting all outbound HTTP requests
so it's basically checking hey is there
logic for this in the Wom if there is
let the WOM handle it and do that before
actually going and accessing the network
and so this is how we accomplish that
local first thing if you have if your
handler doesn't need a network then
